articles.headline: Investors Seek Out Safer Shores
articles.snippet: With the world in financial turmoil, and Treasury bond yields at record lows, American investors are turning to places like Norway, Sweden, Canada and Australia as safe havens.
articles.abstract: With the world in financial turmoil, and Treasury bond yields at record lows, American investors are turning to places like Norway, Sweden, Canada and Australia as safe havens.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pine-accented Manhattan outpost of Norway’s biggest bank, high in a Midtown skyscraper, is an unlikely shelter in a global financial storm.

articles.headline: Hospital Chain Inquiry Cited Unnecessary Cardiac Work
articles.snippet: HCA, the largest for-profit hospital chain in the country, uncovered evidence of unnecessary — even dangerous — cardiac treatments at some of its medical centers in Florida.
articles.abstract: HCA, the largest for-profit hospital chain in the country, uncovered evidence of unnecessary — even dangerous — cardiac treatments at some of its medical centers in Florida.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2010, a troubling letter reached the chief ethics officer of the hospital giant HCA, written by a former nurse at one of the company’s hospitals in Florida.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Quick Lunge for a Lifeline Helped Knight Capital Skirt Collapse
articles.snippet: Knight Capital was given a $400 million shot in the arm by a varied group of investors as it narrowly avoided filing for bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: Knight Capital was given a $400 million shot in the arm by a varied group of investors as it narrowly avoided filing for bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Thomas M. Joyce arrived at Knight Capital’s Jersey City offices on Sunday, the fate of his company and the legacy of his long Wall Street career were in jeopardy. His lawyers were preparing a potential bankruptcy filing throughout the day, according to people briefed on the matter, and the company’s last hope rested with an eclectic group of investors.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: Why Are Investors Fleeing Equities? Hint: It’s Not the Computers
articles.snippet: Analysts cite trading blunders as the reason billions of dollars are flowing out of the stock market, but there might be a simpler reason: a lack of trust.
articles.abstract: Analysts cite trading blunders as the reason billions of dollars are flowing out of the stock market, but there might be a simpler reason: a lack of trust.

articles.headline: Best Buy Founder Makes Bid for a Takeover
articles.snippet: Richard M. Schulze, who founded the company with a single audio equipment store in 1966, announced on Monday a proposal that would give the company a market value of $8.8 billion.
articles.abstract: Richard M. Schulze, who founded the company with a single audio equipment store in 1966, announced on Monday a proposal that would give the company a market value of $8.8 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Best Buy has been troubled by declining sales and growing competition from the likes of Wal-Mart Stores and Amazon.com.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: Fed Officials Underscore Divisions Over Action
articles.snippet: Eric S. Rosengren, president of the Boston Fed, said significant economic indicators were showing weakness, reinforcing the need for the Fed to expand its holdings.
articles.abstract: Eric S. Rosengren, president of the Boston Fed, said significant economic indicators were showing weakness, reinforcing the need for the Fed to expand its holdings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A senior Federal Reserve official said Monday that the employment data released last week had reinforced his view that the Fed must act to increase economic growth.

articles.headline: Iran Envoy Casts Syria as Part of Wider Conflict
articles.snippet: Dispatching the personal representative of its paramount leader to Damascus, Iran moved to reframe the conflict as part of a battle with the United States and others.
articles.abstract: Dispatching the personal representative of its paramount leader to Damascus, Iran moved to reframe the conflict as part of a battle with the United States and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT — Iran moved on Tuesday to reframe the Syrian conflict as part of a wider battle with the United States and other hostile world powers, dispatching the personal representative of its paramount leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, to Damascus for a televised display of solidarity with Syria’s president as battles raged and dozens of Iranian hostages in rebel custody were threatened with death.
